title: Commander Keen 64 Beta
content:
Here goes nothing! [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-smile.gif[/img]

Here is Keen 64 Beta, a game I have been working on since August (on and off though ). It's one level and it's based off Keen 1, but with 3D graphics. It's the groundwork if I continue with this game, and I would add more levels, and more Keen elements.

I wanted to add sound so badly, but when I would rip sounds from Keen 1, it would sound scratchy when played in the game and I just wanted to get this out.

Many thanks to everyone on this thread for making this game better thanks to all of the feedback. If there is any problem with downloading, unzipping, or running the game tell me, same with any errors or bugs anyone may find.

WARNING: READ BEFORE YOU DOWNLOAD
When you unizp the file, make the directory of the program start in c:\keen64beta otherwise the level map textures won't show up!!!!

If the level map textures still don't show up please tell me!!!!

Download Link:
[url=http://www.gigafiles.co.uk/files/5827/Keen64Beta.zip]www.gigafiles.co.uk/files...64Beta.zip[/url]

Screenshot:
[img]http://img.photobucket.com/albums/v337/Tirqin/Keen7a.jpg[/img]

Original Thread on PCKF:
[url=http://p072.ezboard.com/Commander-Keen-3D-Beta/fpubliccommanderkeenforumfrm17.showMessage?topicID=1170.topic]p072.ezboard.com/Commande...1170.topic[/url]

Just a note, if you lose, and get a game over, whenever you select 'new game', it just reverts to the game over screen.

---Freeyorp

title: Re: Commander Keen 64 Beta
content:
The game shouldn't be so, I dunno...platformic? The level design is boring and devoid of anything. The reason games like Mario 64 work so well is because of the feeling of being in a huge world yet to be explored. This game doesn't really feel truly three-dimensional. It feels like some kind of coiled two-dimensional game. So essentially it's Keen 1 except you have to turn around all the time. Also, the gravity is largely unconvincing. You shouldn't be able to adjust where you're landing so late after the declining arc of the jump. I feel like Mary Poppins floating slowly to the ground all the time.

So basically what I want to say is just make sure you don't compromise the playability of the game for the sake of replicating the mechanics of the original.[center]TOUGH GUYS DON'T FOLLOW FADS[/center]

title: Okie dokie...
content:
@Djaser

"Ok here's a problem when I unzip the game he gives a memory problem but when I keep it zipped I can play it."

That's odd, when I download it myself and try it out, it works just the opposite. I will see if it works on another computer.

"About the game: unlike Keen Dreams 3d this one is really playable even though it doesn't look as good."

Well, I'm glad there's progress over the last 3D keen game, gameplay wise. Graphics wise: I hope you mean "doesn't look as good" about the enviroment, which I admit, my level isn't that colorful or texturally detailed (though I don't like some of Dreams 3D's choice of textures), but I do think that the Keen model is superior to the one in Dreams 3D and our enemy models are about on the same same level [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-smile.gif[/img]

"I would advice to drop the live system and start working with continue point because it isn't fun in a game where you can fall to dead so easily to start all over again."

I know what you mean. I think that's why when Mario 64 went 3D they implemented the health system. Which I could add a health system, the hard part is keeping it in the style of Keen.

Many thanks for the criticisim [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-smile.gif[/img]

@grafix Thank you for mirroring it Grafix! [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-grin.gif[/img]

@lv4n many thanks! [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-smile.gif[/img]

@freeyorp101 Thank you!

Thank you for pointing this out, I will try to fix this. In the meantime, to tie up loose ends I think I will make it driectly quit, rather than go through to the menu and not have it work. I got it to restart the game (from what I can tell), but I can't move keen around.

@allstories

"The level design is boring and devoid of anything."

I threw it together for the beta.

"The reason games like Mario 64 work so well is because of the feeling of being in a huge world yet to be explored. This game doesn't really feel truly three-dimensional. It feels like some kind of coiled two-dimensional game."

Well I hate to mention my ideas so early, but since you are basing this on one makeshift level. When or if I would make Keen 64 (full version), I was planning on using a level hub that you can explore and thus access the levels from there (like in games such as Mario 64, Sonic Adventure, Commander Keen series and Keen Dreams 3D). And so the levels accessed would be a tad more linear, because even the levels accessed from the hubs in Mario 64 were linear.

"So essentially it's Keen 1 except you have to turn around all the time."

lol, well that was kind of the point.

"Also, the gravity is largely unconvincing. You shouldn't be able to adjust where you're landing so late after the declining arc of the jump."

Please clearify [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-smile.gif[/img]

Also, do you think having a free camera (ie controled by a mouse), would give you freedom to plan your falls?

"So basically what I want to say is just make sure you don't compromise the playability of the game for the sake of replicating the mechanics of the original."

Ok, I will keep that in mind [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-smile.gif[/img] Thank you for the honest criticisim [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-smile.gif[/img]

@ Everyone

If anyone has the same problem as Djaser with the zip file please tell me so I know if it's just his computer or if it's mine.

title: Hooom.
content:
Experiment with different configurations of points. Putting a chunk of them together might work in a 2D platformer, but in a 3D environment you need to be more creative. Space them out a bit. Less is more.

The ability to strafe would be nice, and I'm all for a movable camera.

The 3D models need some depth to them. Gargs and yorps should have spheroid bodies. Aside from that, they're looking good. The lollipops also look too flat. I was always under the impression that the Keen 1 lollipops were spherical. If you stick with flat ones, I suggest making them spin or something.

Finally, the creatures need to move freely around the platforms, rather than linearly as they currently do.

It's an impressive start to the second ever 3D Keen fangame, and I look forward to improvements.

title: whee
content:
Good work so far! There are a few issues I have with the game as it is, but nonetheless the progress made is promising.

The main problem is the camera - as various people have pointed out, it makes jumping and moving in general pretty hard. The camera in most good 3D platformers moves around to follow the player, rather than just hovering behind them in the same place; this is especially useful near hazards obscured by cliffs. If you could implement that at some point, rather than require the player to move the camera every time they approached an edge, it would make the game much more playable.[url=http://toxicsheep.com]toxicsheep.com[/url] | [url=http://commanderkeen.org]coming up next...[/url]

title: well
content: This looks like a good start--just get a Mars-y skybox, and then start adding huge expanses of barren red planet, and you'll be in much better shape.

@KeenRush

Thanks a ton KeenRush!

@ceilick

Thank you [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-smile.gif[/img]

Yeah, I noticed that myself about walking past the gargs, though in Keen 1 there were times when you could bypass them. But in 64 it's way too easy lol.

@Commander Spleen

I totally agree with the points part, but when I was experimenting with Keen in 3D for the first time I had to slurge haha.

Strafe? Maybe, if it doesn't fit snuggly in my control scheme I'll make them extra. [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-wink.gif[/img]

The enemy models, the yorps I think I will leave, I shrink the edges a tad, and the Gargs I think need more depth as well.

The lollypop models, well looking at them in the original, their shininess indicates spherical, but most completely spherical lollypops have longer handles and smaller candy, I think I might keep the main shape but make the sides more like a dome. And I actually made them spin originally, but the ones on the top of the level had problems with spinning.

Yeah, that's what I would like to fix, their robot-ness. I might still retain their main path, but when they see you, they will follow \ chase you and then go back to their path.

Many thanks for the criticisim [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-smile.gif[/img]

@grafix

Thank you [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-smile.gif[/img]

I understand your point. Though even most good 3D platformers excell in gameplay but completely lack in camera, which alters the gameplay. Mario 64, considered one (if not the) of the greatest platformers, but it's camera is horrible, and Sunshine didn't improve in this area much. Sonic Adventure imo had great gameplay, but a horrendous camera, it's sequel didn't improve it much either, like Sunshine.

I think a player controlled camera is something game developers should give the player. Because the cameras in Mario 64 \ Shine and Sonic Adventure 1 \ 2 had a common problem, they tried doing too much for the player. When Sonic Adventure DX came out for Gamecube, I thought they fixed it a little, because it gave you feature to control the camera more freely, but my hopes were dashed when the camera would return to normal when I would move my character. If the camera would stay it would've been fantastic, but like Mario 64\ Shine and SA1 \ 2, you could only get a glimpse of what was there but taking that glimpse and using so you could see where you were going was a different story.

So I want to give the player about the same or a little more control (not too much or it will be too complicated) as a regular 3D platformer, but alot of freedom - to move the camera around to where you want it - and make it stay.

@XkyRauh2001

Sounds good to me, I think this will help the look alot, thank you! [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-grin.gif[/img]

LAVA89

title: Re: RE: Shadow Master
content:
if this is your first game I'm amazed even though I can see clearly it's made in Blitz 3D(and not only because of the icon) with little physics knowledge. You should look at the source of one of the examples of Blitz 3D which has a jumping 'Mario'.

As for the camera: I think 3D Platformers are not very suited for PC keyboards and really need a controller.
So a free camera movement is needed. For some things it might move to a fixed camera position(believe me, the creators of Super Mario 64, etc. did add this with purpose, because in some areas with free movement camera it's harder than you think(spiral towers mainly)) that can be overwritten with mouse movements. You can use the mouse for camera movement.
Make sure the movement is relative to camera and not to the character and make sure the camera does not flip too fast. You could use some code like this:

camerax=oldcamerax*(SMOOTHNESS)+wantedcamerax*(1.0-SMOOTHNESS)
cameray=oldcameray*(SMOOTHNESS)+wantedcameray*(1.0-SMOOTHNESS)

in this case SMOOTHNESS is a value between 0.0 and 1.0 with 0.0 meaning instant flipping the camera and 1.0 with never moving the camera. You should try to find a value between 0.0 and 1.0 for it that seems to work fine if you get the camera working.

And I love frustration in a platform game so I personally like the platformness:PIf Dopefish is for real, what would it be evolved from?

title: Re: therealdopefish
content:
No, this is not my first game, if you go on the thread for this game in the "Unoffical games" thread. In my first post I have links to my other games. This is however my 2nd programmed 3D platformer, the first was another beta of a game, and I'm not too proud of it, though with all I have learned from this game I might update it.

Yes, I'm sure you could tell it was Blitz3D, because it was so amateur lol.

I'll check out the example again, I never really looked it over because the jumping in it is flawed compared to mine (for instance he can keep jumping in midair before he even hits the ground, which last checked is not the case in mine, and if it is...please tell me!!!! haha).

It's not that I have little physics knowledge, I just didn't implement that knowledge. Most of the programming was done in a crunch in the last days of January so I was suprised things are as good as they are. I am taking physics right now and I am doing very well in it, I considered implementing some of the formulas in it while crunching to make it, but I didn't have time. And I now plan to (Globox suggesting it backed up the idea).

I agree they need a controller, but heh, who has a controller? I could add a fixed camera for certain areas, like sprials, that does sound like a good idea.

I have a controller, I'm not sure about anyone else, but I could program it in and let people switch.

Agreed, I admit the games' jumping and movement is a little rough around the edges. My main focus was to get it all working without major problems. My focus now will be to add upon my good base to make it meet up to the standards and smooth things out.

Many thanks [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-wink.gif[/img]

title: RE: ZidaneA and Commander Spleen
content:
Ok, I'll check out Lego Star Wars 2 demo for style ideas.

I also have a PS2-style controller, so I will base it off that. [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-wink.gif[/img]

I tried out MDK and I really like the controls! I think for Keen 64 the keyboard controls will be WASD for movement, and the mouse for turning and looking up, then left mouse button will shoot and right button will jump.

Also in the beta, I have an option where you can switch the camera modes, so if it's in the 2nd mode, you can turn 360 around keen. Well in the next update I will include that, but instead when the 2nd cam mode mode is set, the mouse will be able to zoom out and turn 360 instead of delete and pg down being the buttons to turn 360 and not having a zoom button.

Then for the joystick, 1st stick will be movement, 2nd stick will be camera (360-turn and zoom) that will switch to when R trigger will be pressed. Also left trigger will be fire.

Thanks ZidaneA and Commander Spleen! [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-grin.gif[/img]

title: Re: Okie dokie...
content:
oh yea, i remember i could jump in the air again in that demo, but the jump is smoother than your jump. You don't need work out physics but you could have something like this:
[pre] if onAPlatform then if(jumpButton and not previousFrameJumpButton)then speedy=15 else speedy=-1 end ifelse if(jumpButton and speedy>0) speedy-=0.5 else speedy-=1.0 end ifend ify+=speedy;onAPlatform=(collission(floors));previousFrameJumpButton=jumpButton;[/pre]
And I advise to make difference between ceilings, walls and floors somehow in your level or you can perform wall jumps and ceiling jumps too.
Good luck on the physics.

title: Re: Okie dokie...
content:
Okay, I finally got around to playing this...

-You should probably add some regular Mars ground. It will make the game feel more like Mars, and make it harder to fall into an endless abyss.

-This has probably been said, but the cylinder blocks shouldn't be striped. They were like that in the original game because it was the best way to shade a cylinder with only 16 colors. Of course, you could always keep it for texture, but the top shouldn't have stripes.

-Yeah, improve on the jumping. Also, Keen should only be able to turn as he walks, not while he just stands there.

-The stars in the background shouldn't move with the rest of the map. It feels as though the stars are just outside the level, rather than far out in space. Also, the original game wasn't really at night. Maybe use a gray sky, rather than night?-Genius314

title: 3D Thinking Yorp?
content:
Ok, I am working on the Yorp AI, I added the little hops (it's rough around the edges, he just goes up real quick then falls down every so often). Now I am working on the "thinking" and following movements, but before I add that, I want to make a new animation of the Yorp "thinking" (when he looks side to side).

So what I want to ask is-- what would the Yorp look like thinking in 3D? In the original games, he looks to side to side, and in 2D that was perfect, but would he be doing in 3D? Since it's hard to tell what a completely 2D character would be doing in 3D.

In the 2D games, he faces the direction he is moving then when he thinks he turns to the side and moves his eye back and forth, now this is possible in my game, but that would look weird, in my opinion.

There are some other ideas of what he could do, like would he turn from side to side (facing forward)? Will he look behind himself then in front? Will he move his eye from side to side (facing forward)? Or something different?

I could always decide myself, but I think asking what you guys think is better. [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-smile.gif[/img]

title: Re: 3D Thinking Yorp?
content:
Yeah, I think looking over his "shoulder" with the eye-stalk would be a good way of doing the "thinking animation for the Yorp.

With the Garg (for the future), a combination of eye-stalks and face tilt.--------------------

title: Theatrics

Kind of hard to describe, but basically instead of the eystalk moving in a straight line from side to side, it swivels out as the eye is rotating.

title: Shuffling Yorp
content:
Both interesting ideas. I had one new idea, which the Yorp wouldn't really move his eye, but he turn around confused till he found Keen, then he would continue following him. What do you guys think of that? It's just an idea.

title: Hehe
content:
Really, what would be damn cool (but not easy, if you're coding this yourself) would be to have the Yorp's eye point in the direction of nearby info_nodes that you placed in the environment... So that when he stood still to look around, he'd glance in their direction--at least, his little eyeball would point at them.

This way, when you're designing your levels, you can put the little info_nodes on cool pieces of scenery, maybe platforms that are off to a side, or a clam plant. Also, make it so other monsters, and Keen himself, are entities the Yorp will glance at.

If you can get all that working, the Yorp will wander around, glance at a few key places (you decide) in the environment, and even check Keen out as he approaches. That'd be damn cool.

title: Re: Jimmy
content:
Ok....let me put it this way.

You have the platformer level that was in the beta, it's just like the cities you go into on Keen 1. They have items to collect, enemies to shoot, etc, just like the levels in Keen 1.

Then you have the Map level, like in Keen 1 it's hub with access to the different cities (aka Platformer levels).

Finally you have the secret map level. But I only call it a map level because you can only explore it, you can't shoot or collect anything. But it's not like the map level, because you can't access the platformer levels from it.

content:

Remember that in the Keen 1 story, the Martians consider ALL toys to be "holy", so the pogo stick isn't really that much different.



I tried to play the Keen 64 demo, but it wouldn't work. I followed all the instructions, but when I ran the EXE, a 640x480-size window popped up, and then after a couple seconds, I got a message saying "unable to set graphics mode." I have a Windows XP with 256 MB of RAM and just under a gigahert of speed, and earlier tried it on a Windows ME with the same capacities and got the same results.

content:
It means that for some reason, your video card cannot switch to the game's resolution mode. Seeing as the resolution is a standard 4:3 resolution (640x480) this is pretty weird, though. Tried installing the latest video card drivers?____________

content:

title: Re: Keen 64
content:
I found out why it wouldn't work on my computer. My video adapter only allowed 16-bit and 24-bit color palettes, and Keen 64 apparently needs 32-bit. I tried it with a 32-bit-enabled adapter and it will run, albeit very slowly.

However, the textures won't show up. I've tried playing the game with the files being in C:\keen64beta\*.*, C:\keen64\keen64beta\*.*, and C:\keen64beta\keen64\*.*, and the textures wouldn't show up no matter what.

I suggest you add a feature to optionally move Keen in relation to the camera instead of using the left and right keys to turn. It would make it more classic and also allow your Keen model to be seen from more angles. WIth the current controls, it can get annoying waiting for Keen to turn 360 degrees just to shoot a Garg or something! [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-smile.gif[/img]

title: Re: Damien SR
content:
File path:

It should work if the folder containing the exe is on the C drive, so like C:\Keen64Beta, but you've already tried that it seems.

Does anyone else have textures not working? (Compare the way the game looks on your computer to the pictures to know for sure)

Because some people I noticed didn't realize that if the map is white the intended textures weren't working, so please make sure the map isn't white so I know what is being done wrong and what is being done right.

For the demo I figured out a solution for it so it *should* work in the next revision.

Turning controls:

Yeah that's a good point, even though it's still being refined, in the demo I have made it so when you press left he's automatically turned left and moving left and so on, like in the 3D Sonic or Mario games.

title: Demo Update
content:
Ok, recently I've been working on the controls. So here is an update of my progress:

Joystick & Camera: Having a Joystick might be scrapped till the full version. I have been having problems with the joystick and playing the game (aiming for platforms, movement too sensitive, etc), this could be some bad level design on my part because the level has alot of endless pits, as Genius314 mentioned before, so it wouldn't really be till the full version that I could make levels more adapted for the game pad.

I could just leave it to the Keyboard & Mouse, but I'd hate to cut back on features and leave them for the full game. And I did get the controls set up, I just needed the camera to update properly, so I could do this as the last area in the demo.

Either way it's not too much trouble, I just don't want to have a bunch of control problems for people.

What do you guys think? Considering the problems mentioned in this post...should I still bother putting in gamepad support for the demo?

Jumping: DaVince, I noticed you said on the first page of this thread to make the jumps exponential, if I was to do that, what would that look like? (visually, I'm not talking from the programming side) And what would be the difference between that and linear jumping? [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-smile.gif[/img]

title: Re: Demo Update
content:
[hr]Lava DaVince, I noticed you said on the first page of this thread to make the jumps exponential, if I was to do that, what would that look like?
[hr]It would look just as in the Keen games, and indeed most platform games. Mathematically it would look like an upside-down [url=http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parabola]parabola[/url].

For example, an object has an initial jumping rate of 10 units. Every fraction of a second, the value is added to the object's height, and reduced by one. So a fraction of a second later, the object moves up 9 more units.

Eventually it reaches zero, at which point it stops increasing and sits there for a moment. Then the value becomes -1 and the object goes back down at an increasing rate (up until a maximum velocity of, say, 10) until it hits something.

That's how it's usually done in 2D platformers, anyway.

title: Re: Demo Update
content:
Yup, it'd look like a smooth jump with a bit more gravity rules applied (velocity). Linear would be if you leave out the velocity, which results in a "move up at a constant speed until you suddenly fall down again at a constant speed" behaviour.____________
